subject: Ethics
title: Bioethics in Space
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Bioethics in Space.

hook.text: An astronaut on Mars needs surgery. The only doctor is 20 light-minutes away on a screen. Now what?

buildup.text: Space missions raise bioethics questions Earth never had to face: radiation, isolation, limited resources.

discovery.text: Should we genetically modify astronauts for radiation resistance? What about reproduction in space?

twist.text: A Mars colony can't medevac anyone. Triage rules written for hospitals don't work 225 million km away.

climax.text: Space forces bioethics to rethink autonomy, consent, and acceptable risk from the ground up.

punchline.text: New worlds need new ethicsâ€”the old ones don't travel well.

quiz.question: Why does space colonization challenge existing bioethical frameworks?
options: Space has no gravity, making medical procedures easier
Extreme isolation, limited resources, and communication delays create unprecedented ethical situations
All current bioethics laws automatically apply in space
